content:
I'm a bit sad because I just got this clash in Fastest mode.

My first thought was :"Oh, if this had been Shortest mode I would have used Chinese remainder theorem. But it's Fastest, so I have to bruteforce it instead"

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple puzzle. This would be interesting in Shortest mode.
I personally like the problem, but I'm afraid that without a decent mathematical background this can become a 1h problem rather than a 5 minutes one.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: No problems, and possible to solve quickly.

Minor suggestion: "I pick a number [[N]] between {{0}} and {{100}}" --> add " (inclusive)" there.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: c'est fun

The minus sign does not make a good bullet symbol. Use • or ➤ or similar, or instead write [[a]] = 0 without the bullet, and I will approve.

Consider that constraints might be clearer as 0 ≤ [[a]] < 3, etc.

This is a pretty easy clash, so I would not include % anywhere in the problem statement, to let people who need to think about it discover it on their own. The modulo operator is also not % in some languages.

If you want to make it more difficult, you could wander into negative territory, which isn't handled correctly in some languages. But that's also a bit evil.
42 doesn't seem to be an edge case to me, and Validator 1 need not be the same as Test 1. Please change Validator 1 to be different from Test 1. Thanks.

Good application for a "clash" involving the Chinese Remainder Theorem.

Everything seems correct since  N is less than 105, and the problem statement appears clear to me.
Quick and Fun. Maybe just change the "N" in the example to [[N]]. :)
I had to look this up to be sure, and thought I'd share here. The divisors do not have to be prime, but they should be pairwise coprime for that to apply. So e.g. 5, 6, 7 or 7, 8, 9 would also work.

I had removed some % signs for the same reasons but had missed the ones in the input.
All good points, amendments done.
I feel like sometimes it's fine to underspecify a problem, if it's otherwise handled well. The details can be found in the constraints.
There's the option to iterate and test the numbers to 100, that is the safe option for everyone.

Underspecify: fine. Misspecify: not. I'm not a native English speaker, but I am under the impression that 'between' without specification technically means exclusive. While such a misdirect would not make the clash too hard, if indeed it is a misdirect I do not like it (since people interpreting the statement correctly at first would be punished with timeloss).

So, it hinges on what between technically means. I did not know for sure, hence I did not build my approval on it.

In spoken language, "between" can be either inclusive or exclusive. For instance, "number between 1 and 3" is very common and clearly inclusive, while "stop between home and work" is clearly exclusive. I don't doubt that, in technical contexts, it's more typically exclusive, because people tend to use more discretion in such contexts, and not so much in spoken language. It's the same sort of ambiguity with "if" and "must" and many other natural language constructs.

What should trigger a heightened awareness in this problem is the use of zero as the starting point. The range is akin to a percentage, which is by default inclusive in the same sense that a probability being naturally bound between 0 and 1 doesn't need further clarification. However, the use of zero in a computing context raises another possibility that doesn't occur naturally in language: 0 inclusive and 100 exclusive. So I definitely classify this particular phrasing as underspecified, and felt justified in approving the clash as unambiguous because it is specified in the constraints.

If after this explanation you feel that the phrasing is misspecified or even just misleading, then I will value that intuition and encourage you to say as much. My comment above follows the line of thinking that these sorts of questions come up in real life and shouldn't always be scrubbed if deliberated and found within reason. It may annoy someone to have to change their bounds, and they may even protest temporarily, but they may have also learned something, and learning is not often a joyful process.
